subject: Data
title: Edward Tufte and the Ink-to-Data Ratio
description: A short lesson to help you apply Edward Tufte and the Ink-to-Data Ratio.

hook.text: In 1983, a Yale professor self-published a book about charts that became the bible of data design.

buildup.text: Edward Tufte argued that every drop of ink on a chart should represent data â€” nothing decorative.

discovery.text: His 'data-ink ratio' principle: maximize the data shown per unit of ink. Erase everything non-essential.

twist.text: Tufte's book sold over 2 million copies, entirely through self-publishing. No publisher wanted it.

climax.text: His principles transformed how organizations design dashboards, reports, and presentations.

punchline.text: Good charts don't decorate. They communicate.

quiz.question: What does Tufte's 'data-ink ratio' principle advocate?
options: Maximizing data shown per unit of ink
Making charts as large as possible
